_exec_summary.SummaryText:
JENNINGS-GOMER EQUITY, INC. - BEAVERDAM BRANCH
RMP Executive Summary - Anhydrous Ammonia


The accidental release prevention and emergency response policy:  The location and design of this system complies with the Ohio Administrative Code 901:5-3-01 to 901:5-3-14, "Regulations for Storing and Handling Fertilizer Anhydrous Ammonia", as administered and enforced by the Ohio Department of Agriculture.  It is the policy of this facility to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  Management and employees are commited to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, county LEPC, EPA and any other applicable authorities to mitigate the release and minimize its inpact on people and the environment.


A description of the facility and the regulated substance handled:  The primary activity at this faciltiy is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  The facility has one Anhydrous Ammonia storage tank that holds 30,000 gallons or 140,000 pounds of product at one time.  Lord's Enterprises owns this tank but it is currently leased by Jennings-Gomer Equity.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, filled into nurse tanks, and sold to farmers for direct application as a crop production nutrient.


The worst-case release scenario:  The worst-case scenario is the release of the total contents of the largest storage tank or rail tank car released as a gas over a period of 10 minutes.  The maximum quanity released would be 140,000 pounds, which is the volume of the largest storage tank filled to 85% as limited by design capacity.  The distance to endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 1.16 miles (The Fertilizer Institute's Worst-Case Anhydrous Ammonia Releases Table 1).  There are about 100 homes and a total population of 300 within the distance to the endpoint.


The alternative release scenario:  The alternative release sc

enario, based on the mos likely potential incident, is a release from a transfer hose failure (1.5" hose).  Based on The Fertilizer Institute's Alternate-Case Releases of Anhydrous Ammonia Table 1, assuming that the release is stopped by active/passive mitigation after 2 minutes and a wind speed of 3 meters/second,  at 3500 lb/min, 7000 lb would be released effecting an 0.46 mile radius.  There are about 60 homes and a population of 150 people within the distance to the end point.


Th general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:  This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1" published by The American National Standards Institute (ANSI), and the standards of the US Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  All employees are trained in the equipment safety features and the safe handling of anhydrous ammonia.


The five year accident history:  There has been no accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that has caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility.


The emergency response program:  The facility has a written Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OSHA standards, 29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training. 
A copy of the Emergency Action Plan will be made available for the local Fire Department and Local Emergency Planning Committee.  The company submits annual community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).


Planned changes to improve safety:  Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facitilty.  Company personnel and the Ohio Department of Agriculture conduct periodic evaluations to assure safety equipment and procedures are being followed correctly.
